content:
Short-circuit logic is not only about concision—it’s a practical tool to avoid errors and avoid unnecessary work.

---
## 1) Guarding attribute access

```python
user = None

if user is not None and user.get("active"):
    print("active user")
else:
    print("no active user")
```python

---
## 2) Avoid expensive work unless needed

```python
import time

def expensive():
    time.sleep(0.1)
    return True

flag = False

if flag and expensive():
    print("ran")
else:
    print("skipped")
```python

Because `flag` is False, `expensive()` is never called.

---
## 3) Defaulting with or (with a caution)

```python
name = ""
display = name or "(anonymous)"
print(display)
```python

This works well when empty values should fall back to a default. If empty is meaningful, be explicit:

```python
name = ""
if name == "":
    display = "(empty string)"
else:
    display = name
print(display)
```python

---
## 4) any/all with generator expressions

```python
password = "Abc123"

has_digit = any(ch.isdigit() for ch in password)
has_upper = any(ch.isupper() for ch in password)
long_enough = len(password) >= 6

if has_digit and has_upper and long_enough:
    print("ok")
else:
    print("try again")
```python

---
## 5) Practice block: validate a record safely

```python
record = {"name": "ana", "age": "20"}

name_ok = bool(record.get("name"))
age_text = record.get("age")
age_ok = age_text is not None and age_text.isdigit() and 0 <= int(age_text) <= 120

if name_ok and age_ok:
    print("valid")
else:
    print("invalid")
```
title: Short-circuit conditionals in practice: safe guards and optional values
